div1.head: Jim to Mademoiselle Marcelle Guerin June 4th 1916
div1.p:
I left Luxeuil the 31st of May late in the afternoon and landed at Toul where I spent the night. There was heavy mist the next morning and I did not get away until after eight. I landed on the bad field here half an hour afterwards. The escadrille was to go out at 12.30 and so I made ready. I had seen no map and looked at my aerial one for first time on climbing into the machine. I counted on following the others. Two of us left. As the third was starting he glanced up and saw fourteen Boches overhead. Five mounted to the attack. I passed right under them without seeing the enemy. The Boches, as you have read in the papers, dropped a great number of bombs. Fifty people were killed and four times that number wounded. Our five machines attacking got the worst of it. The Germans used explosive bullets. Two ^of our planes were forced to come down and the others couldn’t do anything. My old ambulance section happens to be here and they picked up the wounded. Dear, old Lovell stood right (over)
in the place where the bombs were falling and directed his cars. He is leaving in a few days to join the aviation corps.

Well I lost myself as I had presumed I would and tho [sic] over the lines didn’t know where. Looking down to my left I saw a machine. “Ha,” said I “One of ours” and felt happy. Then I saw the crosses. A Boche! First one I’d seen from the air. I did not know the slightest thing about how to attack and I had never fired my mitrailleuse in the air. It was with a queer feeling that I shut off my power, dove towards the enemy plane and put my hand on the release of my machine gun. When within fifty meters the Boche saw me and opened fire. I sighted and gave him a round with no results. My speed carried me beyond. I turned and found myself just behind sighting into the flame of his mitrailleuse. I could hear the tut -tut -tut -tut of the gun and then his bullets ripped into my machine with the sound of small explosions. I sighted and fired again. Still nothing doing. I knew I would be
killed in that position — the best possible for the German machine gun operator — and I threw myself onto my right side, mounted and dove again. I pressed my trigger and there was no response. The Boche hit me again. I turned and armed the machine gun. Nothing doing. I tried again. Same result. Then back of me I heard the whirr [sic] and hammer of the mitrailleuse and looking up saw the Boche diving at me and shooting. I put on full power, piced [sic] and lost him. I examined my machine gun and found a bullet had carried away the cartridge container. I tried to locate myself but it was in vain. Then I headed S.W. and picked up a canal. I could not find my bearing and hunted up other canals which I followed up and down. For two and a half hours I did that and then gave it up as a bad job. Just outside of a large town I saw a field that looked like an aviation center of some kind. I came down low and circled around in order to bring out people. I wanted to see if the soldiers were French or (over)
German. I saw the blue uniforms and made for my landing. The field was covered with tall grass and while skimming the surface I hit a bump I could not see and shot up into the air, the machine turned nose down and crash. Every thing broke as I went over on my back. I was at St. Dizier. I took my instruments and in a car motored home. I had been reported as missing and believed dead. I counted nine holes in my machine some of which were not a foot from my head. I’ll have a new machine in a couple of days. You see I am starting out like a dub [sic] so you must not expect much of me.

closer.salute: My best regards to your father and mother and my very best to you.
closer.seg:
P.S. Received a letter from Betty written in her own hand — poor, shaky writing that would almost make one cry, the poor kid, and so I presume she’s doing well now.
Your friend Rumsey arrived to day.
Escadrille N. 124 S.P. 24.
